pageData.text: There are three categories of macronutrients found in food: <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrates</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button>. These large, complex, organic molecules cannot be absorbed unless they are converted to smaller molecules by digestive processes. In this investigation, students will perform standard chemical tests for each of the macronutrients, and then model the digestion of protein and starch.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: One sheet of white paper
Distilled water
Scissors
Ruler (recommended but not required)
Timer or timing device
Container of heated water
Paper towels
Carbohydrate sources such as sugar, fruit or vegetable juice, or bread
Protein sources such as meat, milk, beans, or tofu
Cooking oil, such as vegetable oil or olive oil
Food samples, such as cheese, meat, or vegetables
Vinegar
Mustard or ketchup
Salad dressing
Saltine crackers
Three foods of unknown lipid (fat) content
Digital camera (or mobile device with camera)

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 15 minutes, 
Activity 1: Starch Test – 15 minutes, 
Activity 2: Protein Test – 10 minutes, 
Activity 3: Fat Test – 10 minutes, 
Activity 4: Modeling Gastric Digestion – 60 minutes, 
Activity 5: Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch – 10 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Starch Test - 15 minutes 
Activity 2: Protein Test - 10 minutes 
Activity 3: Fat Test - 10 minutes 
Activity 4: Modeling Gastric Digestion - 60 minutes 
Activity 5: Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch - 10 minutes

pageData.text: Note: Activities should be performed in sequential order. Activity 4 can be started during the reaction time for Activity 3.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Chemical and Physical Digestion

text: Describe the chemical composition of the macronutrients—carbohydrates, <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button>—and also the <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acids</button>.
Describe the function of <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button> in the digestion of food.
Describe specific chemical tests performed on food and explain the results.
Model the <button class='glossary-text'>gastric digestion</button> of protein and salivary digestion of starch.
Evaluate the effects of temperature and pH on chemical digestion.

pageData.text: There are several genetic disorders that prevent affected individuals from properly metabolizing molecules from food. One such disorder is phenylketonuria (PKU), a rare inherited disorder in which the amino acid phenylalanine cannot be metabolized and thus builds up in the body. This build-up can lead to intellectual disabilities, seizures, and mental disorders. In hospitals in the United States, newborns are tested for PKU with a blood test conducted 1-2 days after birth. This is because PKU, although incurable, can be easily treated by starting the infant on a strict diet devoid of phenylalanine. Affected individuals, also known as phenylketonurics, must avoid consuming foods containing substantial amounts of phenylalanine for the rest of their lives.With the widespread use of sugar substitutes, phenylketonurics have had to refine their unique diets. The artificial sweetener aspartame is a which contains phenylalanine. Aspartame is found in foods such as diet sodas and chewing gum - but these foods pose a health risk to phenylketonurics if they are unaware of the chemical composition of aspartame. As a result, the labels on foods containing aspartame or similar substances must include the warning “Phenylketonurics: contains phenylalanine”.

pageData.desc: A man at a table drinking a cold beverage.
pageData.altText: A man at a table drinking a cold beverage.

pageData.text: The main functions of the digestive system are mechanical and chemical digestion, and absorption. Digestion is the process in which the body breaks food down into smaller molecules so that nutrients can be easily absorbed. The entire digestion process can take anywhere from 24 to 50 hours.

pageData.subTitle: Mouth/Esophagus
pageData.text: Digestion begins in the mouth through the mechanical and chemical breakdown of food. Smooth muscle tissue in the esophagus squeezes the food down toward the stomach in a process called peristalsis.

pageData.subTitle: Stomach
pageData.text: Mechanical and chemical digestion continues in the stomach. Smooth muscle tissue in the stomach wall squeezes and churns the material, while enzymes and chemicals are added to help further break down the food.

pageData.subTitle: Stomach structure
pageData.text: The internal structure of the stomach has ridges and folds called rugae. This increases the surface area within the stomach and allows it to expand to hold more food.

pageData.subTitle: Intestines
pageData.text: The small intestine and large intestine (colon) combined average 25 feet long.

pageData.subTitle: Small Intestine
pageData.text: The majority of absorption takes place in the small intestine, which is about 20 feet long. The small intestine has 3 sections: duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.Finger-like extensions called villi and microvilli increase the surface area of the small intestine, allowing maximum absorption of nutrients and water.

pageData.subTitle: <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Large Intestine
pageData.text: The large intestine, about 5 feet long, is responsible for eliminating waste matter.

Food is absorbed by the digestive system only after it is broken down into smaller components. As food passes through the digestive tract, it is broken down through physical digestion processes. Among the constituents of food are biological macromolecules: large, complex organic molecules, most of which are <button class='glossary-text'>polymers</button>: molecules made up of large numbers of repeating units. Chemical digestion is performed by <button class='glossary-text'>enzymes</button> that break these large molecules down into smaller, less complex units which can be absorbed. The individual units of polymers are known as <button class='glossary-text'>monomers</button>. The exact digestive processes, the reaction locations in the digestive tract, and how the body uses the monomers all depend on the molecular composition of the food. There are four categories of biological macromolecules broken down during digestion: <button class='glossary-text'>carbohydrates</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>nucleic acids</button>. The first three are referred to as macronutrients because they constitute the bulk of the diet.

pageData.subTitle: Carbohydrates
pageData.text: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH2O)n. The vital metabolic process of aerobic cellular respiration requires the breakdown of carbohydrates to yield energy for ATP (adenosine triphosphate) production. Carbohydrates also provide a source of carbon for use in the synthesis of many structural materials. Carbohydrates can be assigned to three categories based on their molecular structure: , , and . Monosaccharides are the monomers of carbohydrates. They are the least complex of the carbohydrate molecules and are often called “simple sugars.” Examples of monosaccharides are glucose, fructose, ribose, and deoxyribose. Disaccharides contain two chemically bonded monosaccharides, and include sucrose (table sugar), maltose, and lactose. Polysaccharides are the most complex carbohydrates, and they contain several monosaccharides linked in various configurations. Starch and glycogen are polysaccharides.

pageData.question: What is the general formula of a carbohydrate?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O)<sub class='bodySubscript'>n</sub>.

pageData.question: Which of the following chemical reactions best describes the process of aerobic cellular respiration?

options.text: C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub> + O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> --> ATP + H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O + CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>
C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub> --> O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> + ATP

C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub> + H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O --> O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> + CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>
O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> + ATP --> C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub> + CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>
CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub> + H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O --> C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In the presence of oxygen (O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>), mitochondria break down glucose (C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>) into ATP, water (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O) and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O)<sub class='bodySubscript'>n</sub>. When carbohydrates are consumed, the body breaks them down into glucose (C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>). The transformation of glucose into energy occurs in one of two ways: with oxygen or without it. In mitochondria and in the presence of oxygen (O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>), glucose is converted to energy, or adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This conversion yields not only ATP, but also heat, water (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O), and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbohydrates are organic compounds that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O)<sub class='bodySubscript'>n</sub>. When carbohydrates are consumed, the body breaks them down into glucose (C<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>H<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub>O<sub class='bodySubscript'>6</sub>). The transformation of glucose into energy occurs in one of two ways: with oxygen or without it. In mitochondria and in the presence of oxygen (O<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>), glucose is converted to energy, or adenosine triphosphate (ATP). This conversion yields not only ATP, but also heat, water (H<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>O), and carbon dioxide (CO<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>).

pageData.subTitle: Proteins
pageData.text: are complex organic compounds composed of called (Figure 1). Amino acids contain hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen in the general chemical formula NH2–RCH–COOH, where –R represents hydrogen, a functional group, a carbon chain, or a carbon ring structure. All amino acids are identical except for the –R group. The properties of each amino acid depend on the –R group structure. The body requires nitrogen for the construction of proteins, , and other compounds. Twenty amino acids are encoded by the universal genetic code: these are known as the natural amino acids. These 20 amino acids can be linked together by peptide bonds to form proteins. The linked amino acids can form (pairs of amino acids), (chains of three amino acids), and (chains of many amino acids). The polypeptides may contain any number, sequence, and/or configuration of amino acids to form a vast number of proteins. Thus, the proteins contained in food are a source of prefabricated amino acids. Although some amino acids can be synthesized in the human body, the “essential” amino acids must be supplied in prefabricated form through the diet. Nine amino acids are considered essential.
The absence of any of these halts the synthesis of crucial proteins, resulting in disease, and, in prolonged cases of deprivation, death.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Basic structure of an amino acid
pageData.desc: Figure 1: Basic structure of an amino acid

pageData.subTitle: Lipids
pageData.text: are a diverse group of organic compounds that are classified together because they are soluble in organic solvents (e.g., alcohol, ether, benzene, and acetone), but insoluble in water. Similar to , lipids are composed of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen; however, the percentage of oxygen is much lower. Phospholipids contain phosphorus (P) in addition to carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. Lipids are used primarily for energy and for structural purposes, and include , steroids, phospholipids, waxes, and other lipoid substances. Triglycerides, also known as neutral fats, provide organisms with a concentrated source of energy, yielding twice as many calories per gram as carbohydrates and . They contain three chains bonded to a molecule (a sugar alcohol). Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature (Figure 2). Fatty acids are unsaturated if they contain one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain and are generally liquid at room temperature.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.
pageData.desc: Figure 2: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the chemical structure of a saturated fatty acid?

options.text: It contains only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain.
It contains one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain.
It contains two or more triple bonds between carbons in the chain.
It contains more than three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule.
It contains only one fatty acid chain bonded to a glycerol molecule.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature.

pageData.question: The terms “saturated” and “unsaturated”, when describing fatty acids, refer to what chemical element?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The term saturated indicates that the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms are bonded to each carbon. An unsaturated fatty acid will have fewer hydrogen atoms than a saturated fatty acid of the same chain length.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature. The term saturated indicates that the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms are bonded to each carbon. Fatty acids are unsaturated if they contain one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain and are generally liquid at room temperature. When three fatty acid chains are bonded to a glycerol molecule, the lipid is known as triglyceride. They provide organisms with a concentrated source of energy, yielding twice as many calories per gram as carbohydrates and proteins. Other examples of lipids include steroids, phospholipids, waxes, and other lipoid substances.

img.alt: Figure 2: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Fatty acids are saturated if they contain only single covalent bonds between the carbons in the chain and are generally solid at room temperature. The term saturated indicates that the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms are bonded to each carbon. Fatty acids are unsaturated if they contain one or more double bonds between carbons in the chain and are generally liquid at room temperature. When three fatty acid chains are bonded to a glycerol molecule, the lipid is known as triglyceride. They provide organisms with a concentrated source of energy, yielding twice as many calories per gram as carbohydrates and proteins. Other examples of lipids include steroids, phospholipids, waxes, and other lipoid substances.

img.alt: Figure 2: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.

pageData.subTitle: Nucleic Acids
pageData.text: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA) are biologically important , which function to store and transmit genetic information. Nucleic acids are composed of called . Generally, nucleotides are composed of a sugar, a nitrogenous base, and a phosphate. ATP is a nucleotide consisting of a sugar, a nitrogenous base, and three phosphate groups. ATP is known as the “molecular currency” of intracellular energy because it stores chemical energy within cells in a readily usable form. Other nucleotides have biological significance due to their function in specific biochemical pathways. Although nucleic acids and nucleotides are present in foods, they are not usually considered as macronutrients. Consequently, their digestion will not be discussed in detail here.

pageData.subTitle: Enzymes Aid in Digestion
pageData.text: Most chemical reactions in living organisms would be too slow to sustain life if they were not mediated by specialized called . Enzymes act as catalysts to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the required for the reaction (see Figure 3). Activation energy is the minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction. In the case of digestion, enzymes catalyze the chemical reactions that break down the macronutrients.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Graph depicting the relationships between energy required in order to convert chemical reactants to products. Less energy is required in the presence of an enzyme to catalyze the reaction.
pageData.desc: Figure 3: Graph depicting the relationships between energy required in order to convert chemical reactants to products. Less energy is required in the presence of an enzyme to catalyze the reaction.

pageData.text: An activity is specific for a reaction or a set of reactions. Each enzyme binds exclusively to the or substrates of the reaction(s) it catalyzes. This specific binding occurs because the shape of the enzyme specifically fits or interlocks with the shape of one or more substrates, forming the (see Figure 4). At the end of the reaction, the product or products are released from the enzyme. The enzyme remains unchanged by the reaction; when the reaction is complete, and the enzyme is no longer bound to the substrate(s), the enzyme returns to its original form. The analogy of a “lock and key” was historically used to describe the enzyme-substrate complex. The enzyme has a binding pocket, called an active site, which is shaped to fit a specific substrate. Although this analogy is conceptually helpful, it is somewhat limited. The enzyme-substrate complex is now described by the “induced fit” model, which accounts for the potential shape change of the enzyme when it is bound to its substrate.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing a substrate and enzyme coming together to form an enzyme-substrate complex, and the products separating from the enzyme.
pageData.desc: Figure 4: Diagram showing a substrate and enzyme coming together to form an enzyme-substrate complex, and the products separating from the enzyme.

pageData.text: Various biotic and abiotic factors can influence activity. Enzymes in the body operate best within a narrow range of conditions, including specific temperatures, and product concentrations, salinity, and pH. For example, the digestive system utilizes several enzymes to break down food. Different enzymes operate in different parts of the digestive tract. Some parts of the digestive tract are acidic (pH < 7), whereas other parts are alkaline or basic (pH > 7). Because enzymes are , a shift in pH or other environmental factors may cause (loss of normal structure), resulting in the loss of a functional active site.

There may be other molecules that help or hinder enzyme activity and efficiency by binding to the substrate. Coenzymes and cofactors are activators that increase reaction rates. Cofactors are small, inorganic compounds and ions, whereas coenzymes are organic molecules, such as vitamins.

pageData.question: Historically, the “lock and key” analogy was used to describe the enzyme-substrate complex. Now, it is commonly described by the “induced-fit” model. Which of the following best describes an enzyme in an enzyme-substrate complex, according to the induced-fit model?

options.text: An enzyme may change its shape when binding to a substrate.
Each enzyme has an active site that exactly fits its substrate.
An enzyme can bind to any molecule in the environment by modifying its active site.
An enzyme will deactivate after binding to its substrate.
The shape of an enzyme is permanently changed after binding to a substrate.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The enzyme has a binding pocket, called an active site, which is shaped to fit a specific substrate. However, an enzyme may change shape slightly when it is bound to a substrate.

pageData.question: Which of the following is most likely to happen to an enzyme that is exposed to an environmental change, such as a change in temperature?

options.text: The enzyme changes shape and becomes non-functional.
The enzyme changes its active site and binds to new substrates.
The enzyme becomes dependent on cofactors to function.
The enzyme’s active site assumes a shape more specific to its substrate.
The enzyme migrates to a more ideal environment.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because enzymes are proteins, a shift in pH or other environmental factors may cause denaturation (loss of normal structure), resulting in the loss of a functional active site.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An enzyme may change shape when it is bound to a substrate. The enzyme-substrate complex is now described by the “induced fit” model, which accounts for the potential shape change of the enzyme when it is bound to its substrate. An enzyme’s environment also affects its shape, and therefore its activity. These factors can be biotic or abiotic. For example, different enzymes operate in different parts of the digestive tract: some parts of the digestive tract are acidic (pH < 7), whereas other parts are alkaline or basic (pH > 7). An enzyme that functions best at an acidic pH will not function as well or at all if exposed to an alkaline environment.

img.alt: Figure 5: Diagram of the digestive system

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An enzyme may change shape when it is bound to a substrate. The enzyme-substrate complex is now described by the “induced fit” model, which accounts for the potential shape change of the enzyme when it is bound to its substrate. An enzyme’s environment also affects its shape, and therefore its activity. These factors can be biotic or abiotic. For example, different enzymes operate in different parts of the digestive tract: some parts of the digestive tract are acidic (pH < 7), whereas other parts are alkaline or basic (pH > 7). An enzyme that functions best at an acidic pH will not function as well or at all if exposed to an alkaline environment.

img.alt: Figure 5: Diagram of the digestive system

pageData.subTitle: Digestive Processes
pageData.text: Physical digestion begins in the mouth with , commonly known as chewing (see Figure 5). Mastication grinds food into smaller pieces. Chemical digestion also begins in the mouth, as the food is mixed with saliva excreted from salivary glands in the mouth. Saliva contains the , which catalyzes the breakdown of starch into its component sugars.Starch + Water  Amylase/ ➤ Maltose

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram of the digestive system
pageData.desc: Figure 5: Diagram of the digestive system

pageData.text: The partially digested mass of food, called a , moves from the mouth through the esophagus by muscle action. The esophagus serves as a passageway for the bolus and does not otherwise contribute to physical or chemical digestion. The bolus then reaches the stomach, where occurs. During gastric digestion, glands in the stomach wall secrete and hydrochloric acid (HCl), which are mixed with the bolus by the churning action of muscles in the stomach wall. One of the enzymes, , catalyzes the breakdown of into . Pepsin requires a temperature of approximately 37° C (i.e., body temperature) and low pH to catalyze this reaction. HCl serves to lower the pH, which also inactivates and kills some potentially harmful microorganisms in the food. The product of gastric digestion in the stomach is a semiliquid material called .

The chyme exits the stomach and passes into the duodenum, the first segment of the small intestine. There, it stimulates the production of alkaline intestinal fluids that counteract the acidity of the gastric products. When the acidic chyme becomes alkaline, gastric digestion ceases and <button class='glossary-text'>intestinal digestion</button> begins. Pancreatic juice, or <button class='glossary-text'>pancreatin</button>, is secreted by the pancreas into the duodenum. This liquid contains the enzymes <button class='glossary-text'>amylase</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>trypsin</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>lipase</button>. The amylase in pancreatin, just like that in saliva, breaks down starches into their component sugars. Trypsin hydrolyzes polypeptides, converting them into smaller peptides. Lipase breaks down <button class='glossary-text'>triglycerides</button> into <button class='glossary-text'>glycerol</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>fatty acids</button>. However, <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button> like triglycerides are not soluble in water and must first undergo the process of <button class='glossary-text'>emulsification</button>. Emulsification is not a chemical process (it does not break chemical bonds); rather, it reduces the attraction between fat molecules and disperses them so large droplets become small droplets that can more readily interact with the enzymes. <button class='glossary-text'>Bile salts</button> are emulsifiers that are produced by the liver to assist in the emulsification and digestion of lipids. Bile salts are a component of bile, an alkaline secretion of the liver that is stored and concentrated in the gallbladder before it is released into the duodenum.

The final breakdown of any remaining small peptides to , and also of short chains of saccharides to , is catalyzed by . The brush border is the -bearing surface of the epithelium lining the small intestine. Microvilli are tiny, finger like extensions of the epithelial cells that greatly increase the surface area for nutrient . Several specific to the brush border are responsible for the final stage of chemical digestion.After the breakdown of food in the stomach and small intestine, nutrient absorption must occur. Absorption is the passage of substances through the intestinal mucosa into the blood or lymph. The body cannot absorb , starches, and fats without their first being broken down into their component amino acids, monosaccharides, and . Most nutrient absorption occurs in the small intestine.Water and electrolyte absorption occur in the large intestine. Bacteria inhabiting this part of the digestive tract break down and feed on undigested food material. They also produce vitamin K and certain B vitamins. The undigested material is propelled toward the rectum, and finally eliminated via the anus in the process of defecation.

pageData.subTitle: Substrate Tests
pageData.text: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain macronutrients that serve as for digestive enzymes: (specifically, starches), proteins, and (specifically, fats).Starches can be identified by a simple test using iodine-potassium iodide. In the presence of starch, an iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black. This color change results from iodine binding to the ends of the large starch molecules. The starch you will use in Activities 1 and 2 is derived from potatoes.The protein test used in this kit is called the Biuret test. All compounds that contain peptide bonds will yield a positive result. Thus, all proteins and give a positive test result, but individual amino acids do not. The Biuret reagent is made of sodium hydroxide and copper sulfate. This blue reagent turns purple in the presence of proteins and pink in the presence of amino acids. The albumin you will use in Activities 1 and 2 is a protein found in egg white.

Activity 3 is a quick and safe test for fats. This test uses paper, which can readily absorb fats. This is indicated by the paper turning translucent and remaining that way once the sample has dried. In the absence of , the dry brown paper will appear opaque.In Activities 4 and 5, you will use the starch and tests to observe the action of on these . You will also test the effects of pH and temperature on enzyme action.

pageData.question: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain macronutrients that serve as substrates for digestive enzymes. When iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black, what type of molecule is present in the food sample?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This color change results from iodine binding to the ends of large starch molecules.

pageData.question: Which item on the list below is most likely to cause a dark blue or black color change in iodine-potassium iodide solution?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Polysaccharides are the most complex carbohydrates and will cause a color change in iodine-potassium iodide solution. These carbohydrates are found in food items like bread.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain macronutrients that serve as substrates for digestive enzymes. Starches can be identified by a simple test using iodine-potassium iodide. In the presence of starch, an iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black. The protein test used in this kit is called the Biuret test. All compounds that contain peptide bonds will yield a positive result. The blue Biuret reagent turns purple in the presence of proteins and pink in the presence of amino acids. You will also conduct a quick and safe test for fats. This test uses paper, which can readily absorb fats. This is indicated by the paper turning translucent and remaining that way once the sample has dried. In the absence of lipids, the dry brown paper will appear opaque.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this investigation, you will test for the presence of certain macronutrients that serve as substrates for digestive enzymes. Starches can be identified by a simple test using iodine-potassium iodide. In the presence of starch, an iodine-potassium iodide solution changes color from bright yellow to dark blue or black. The protein test used in this kit is called the Biuret test. All compounds that contain peptide bonds will yield a positive result. The blue Biuret reagent turns purple in the presence of proteins and pink in the presence of amino acids. You will also conduct a quick and safe test for fats. This test uses paper, which can readily absorb fats. This is indicated by the paper turning translucent and remaining that way once the sample has dried. In the absence of lipids, the dry brown paper will appear opaque.

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the test tubes, prepare starch, albumin, and pepsin solutions, and prepare paper squares. In Activity 1, you will conduct starch tests with controls, as well as three food samples. Conduct protein tests with controls, as well as three food samples. If so, yes go forward, if not go back. Conduct quick tests for fats with eight food samples. If so, yes go forward, if not go back. Model the gastric digestion of protein. In Activity 5, you will model the salivary digestion of starch.

text: One sheet of white paper
Distilled water

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Chemical and Physical Digestion investigation (item number 580534) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles, lab apron, and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation, including cleanup and disposal.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Biuret reagent, <button class='glossary-text'>pepsin</button>, and iodine-potassium iodide can be harmful if swallowed and are serious eye irritants.

Hydrochloric acid, Biuret reagent, and iodine-potassium iodide are corrosive materials. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.
Pepsin may cause allergy or asthma symptoms if inhaled. Iodine-potassium iodide can cause an allergic skin reaction.
Hydrochloric acid is toxic if inhaled.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the relationship between an enzyme, a chemical reaction, and activation energy?

options.text: An enzyme catalyzes a chemical reaction by lowering its activation energy.
An enzyme catalyzes a chemical reaction by raising its activation energy.
An enzyme is produced by a chemical reaction when the activation energy is low.
An enzyme is produced by a chemical reaction when the activation energy is high.
An enzyme’s activation energy is lowered as it catalyzes a chemical reaction.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the digestion that takes place in the mouth?

options.text: The mouth digests food chemically and mechanically.
The mouth digests food only chemically.
The mouth digests food only mechanically.
The mouth digests all foods chemically and only some foods mechanically.
The mouth does not participate in digestion.

assestmentData.question: Which term is used for the semi-liquid product of gastric digestion in the stomach?
The digestion of a protein into its monomer units would yield which of the following molecules?
Where in the digestive tract does most of the nutrient absorption occur?

Simon is making qualitative observations of a food sample at room temperature to identify any fats it may contain. Which of the following differences in the physical states of fat is Simon most likely looking for in the sample?

options.text: Saturated fats are solid; unsaturated fats are liquid.
Saturated fats are liquid; unsaturated fats are waxy.
Saturated fats are homogenous; unsaturated fats are heterogeneous.
Saturated fats are heterogeneous; unsaturated fats are homogenous.
Saturated fats are water soluble; unsaturated fats are not water soluble.

assestmentData.question: The pepsin and albumin solutions you will create in Activity 4 will undergo one or both of which of the following sets of treatments?
For this investigation, you will need to provide sources of which of the following types of macromolecules?

options.text: proteins, carbohydrates, nucleic acids, and lipids

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety hazard associated with the Biuret reagent provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: It is a corrosive material and must be used near a safety shower.
It can cause an allergic skin reaction.
It can stain skin or clothing.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following reagents will need to be prepared prior to starting any of the activities in this investigation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure for each activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clear the work area.
Label three test tubes 1–3 with the grease pencil.

Prepare the potato starch solution:
  1. Remove the outer cap and dropper cap from the plastic bottle labeled “Potato Starch.”
  2. Add distilled water to the bottle until it is filled to the neck, and then replace both caps.
  3. Shake the bottle gently until most of the potato starch powder is dissolved. The starch may not dissolve completely. Once the starch solution is prepared, it is best if used within one day.

Prepare the albumin solution:
  1. Remove the outer cap and plastic dropper cap from the bottle labeled “Albumin Powder.”
  2. Add distilled water to the bottle until it is filled to the neck, and then replace both caps.
  3. hake the bottle gently until most of the albumin powder is dissolved. The may not dissolve completely. Once the albumin solution is prepared, it should be used within one day.

Prepare the solution:
  1. Add 25 mL of distilled water to the bottle containing 0.5 g pepsin powder.
  2. Cap the bottle and shake gently to dissolve the pepsin powder. Once the pepsin solution is prepared, it should be used within one day.
Cut the brown paper bag into 8 squares, each approximately 8 x 8 cm.

In Activity 1, you will conduct tests for starch. You will start by observing the iodine-potassium iodide color change with positive and negative controls. Then, you will test several common food items for the presence of starch.
Add 5 mL of distilled water to test tubes 1, 2, and 3.
Shake the potato starch solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 20 drops of potato starch solution to test tube 2.
Shake the albumin solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 20 drops of albumin solution to test tube 3.
Add 4 drops of iodine-potassium iodide solution to test tubes 1, 2, and 3.

Observe the test tubes closely for 30 seconds and record any color changes in Data Table 1. For the best view, hold the test tube against a sheet of white paper to visualize the color. Photograph your results.
Dispose of the test tube contents in the trash or down the drain.
Clean and dry each test tube and graduated cylinder for the next activity.

Repeat Steps 1–7 using at least three common food items such as honey, milk, fruitjuice, fruit, flour, bread, crackers, cooking oils, meat, egg white, fish, and/or dried beans in place of the albumin and starch. Liquids can be used without dilution; solids should be cut or broken into small pieces and mixed with a small amount of distilled water (just enough to form a thick paste).

In Activity 2, you will conduct tests for <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button>. You will start by observing the Biuret reagent color change with positive and negative controls. Then, you will test several common food items for the presence of proteins.
Add 5 mL of distilled water to test tubes 1, 2, and 3.
Shake the albumin solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 10 drops of albumin solution to test tube 2.
Shake the potato starch solution to ensure that it is mixed well. Add 10 drops of potato starch solution to test tube 3.
Add 20 drops of Biuret reagent to test tubes 1, 2, and 3. Tap and swirl each tube to mix the contents completely.

Observe the test tubes closely for 30 seconds and record any changes in Data Table 2. For the best view, hold the test tube against a sheet of white paper to visualize the color. Photograph your results.
Dispose of the test tube contents in the trash or down the drain.
Clean and dry each test tube and graduated cylinder for the next activity.

Repeat Steps 1–7 using at least three common food items such as honey, milk, fruit juice, fruit, flour, bread, crackers, cooking oils, meat, egg white, fish, and/or dried beans in place of the albumin and starch. Liquids can be used without dilution; solids should be cut or broken into small pieces and mixed with a small amount of distilled water (just enough to form a thick paste).

In Activity 3, you will conduct quick tests for <button class='glossary-text'>lipids</button> using brown paper. You will apply several common food items (including positive and negative controls, and three foods of your choice) to brown paper squares, allow them to dry, and observe the presence of grease stains.
Before proceeding, view the video:
Gather the required items.
Draw a circle approximately 2.5 cm in diameter in the center of each square of brown paper.

Label a square on the lower edge of each piece of paper for each of the following: (Unknowns: A–C may be drawn from the list of common food items such as honey, milk, fruit juice, fruit, bread, meat, egg white, etc.)
  1. Water
  2. Vegetable or olive oil
  3. Vinegar
  4. Salad dressing
  5. Mustard or ketchup
  6. Unknown A
  7. Unknown B
  8. Unknown C
Place a sample drop or gently rub the samples on the appropriately labeled square.
Allow the paper to dry for 15 minutes.
Turn over each piece of brown paper to visualize the results on the back of the paper. You may hold the paper up to the light for better visualization of results.
Record the results in Data Table 3 as either a positive reaction (+) or negative reaction (−).
Photograph the 8 pieces of brown paper.

In Activity 4, you will determine the optimal conditions for the <button class='glossary-text'>enzyme</button> <button class='glossary-text'>pepsin</button>, which digests <button class='glossary-text'>proteins</button> in the stomach.

pages.title: Modeling Gastric Digestion of Protein (13 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Modeling Gastric Digestion of Protein (13 steps)

pageData.text: Relabel the test tubes 1a, 1b, 2a, and 2b.
Add warm water (35–40° C) to one foam cup.

Dispense the appropriate liquids into each test tube as directed in Table 1. Shake the albumin solution before dispensing to ensure that it is mixed completely. Be sure to rinse the graduated cylinder with distilled water between uses. If you are using dropper bottles or dropper pipets, you can estimate that 30 drops equal 1 mL.
Add 6 drops of Biuret reagent to test tubes 1a and 2a. Tap and swirl the contents completely.
Hold the tube against a white sheet of paperto visualize the color. Record the color of the contents in Data Table 4.
Take a photograph of your test tubes with the labels clearly visible. You may wish to include a small note or sign to identify the step in the procedure.

Transfer test tubes 1b and 2b to thefoam cup with 35–40º C water in it. Use the thermometer to monitor the water temperature, and add more warm water to the cup if the bath drops below 35º C. Allow the tubes to incubate in the warm water bath for 45 minutes.
Remove the test tubes from the water bath and place them in the test tube rack.
Add 6 drops of Biuret reagent to test tubes 1b and 2b. Tap and swirl each tube to mix the contents completely.

Hold the tube against a white sheet of paper to visualize the color. Any color change you observe will be very subtle. Review the following video on how to interpret Biuret color change to help you identify the color of each test tube. Record the color of the contents in Data Table 4.

pageData.subTitle: How to Interpret Biuret Color Change

pageData.desc: How to Interpret Biuret Color Change

pageData.text: Take a photograph of your test tubes with the labels clearly visible. You may wish to include a small note or sign to identify the step in the procedure.
Dispose of the test tube contents in the trash or down the drain.
Clean and dry each test tube and graduated cylinder for the next activity.
In Activity 5, you will observe how salivary <button class='glossary-text'>amylase</button> digests starch in the mouth using saltine crackers and your own saliva.

pages.title: Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch (10 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Modeling Salivary Digestion of Starch (10 steps)

pageData.text: Place one saltine cracker on a sheet of paper towel.
Fold the paper towel in half and carefully crush the cracker into a fine powder using the bottom of a cup or container.
Carefully pour the cracker crumbs into one of the foam cups.
Add 10 mL of distilled water into the cup with the cracker crumbs. Use a plastic stirrer to mix the water and crumbs together until crumbs are uniformly wet.

Place a second saltine cracker in your mouth. Chew the cracker, without swallowing, for 1 minute. If the cracker is completely chewed before a minute is reached, continue to move the food in your mouth until the time is up.
Carefully spit all the contents of your mouth into the second foam cup. Avoid getting too much of the mixture on the sides of the cup.
Add 10 drops of iodine-potassium iodide solution to each cup. Thoroughly mix the contents of each cup for 30 seconds, using a different plastic stirrer for each.
Allow the cups to sit for 1 minute.
Briefly restir the contents of each cup with their respective stirrers and take a photograph of the inside of each foam cup with a small sign to identify this step.
Complete Data Table 5 and answer any remaining questions.

text: Dispose of the contents of each test tube, and any <button class='glossary-text'>enzyme</button> and/or <button class='glossary-text'>substrate</button> solutions down the drain. Large pieces of substrate, or very thick substrate pastes, may be best disposed of in household trash.

pageData.title: 2.
pageData.text: Dispose of leftover enzyme solutions down the drain. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds afterward.

pageData.title: 3.
pageData.text: Leftover hydrochloric acid may be discarded by pouring it slowly down the drain with copious tap water. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds afterward.

text: Used foam cups and pipets may be disposed of in the trash.
Wash and dry all reusable labware and return to the kit.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

pageData.altText: Basic structure of an amino acid
pageData.content: Figure 1. The parts of a generic amino acid

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A saturated fatty acid molecule on top and an unsaturated fatty acid molecule on bottom.
pageData.content: Figure 2. Saturated versus unsaturated fatty acid structures

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Graph depicting the relationships between energy required in order to convert chemical reactants to products. Less energy is required in the presence of an enzyme to catalyze the reaction.
pageData.content: Figure 3. Energy versus reaction pathway graph with and without an enzyme

pageData.content: Figure 5. Major organs of the digestive system

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, prepare the test tubes, prepare starch, albumin, and pepsin solutions, and prepare paper squares. In Activity 1, you will conduct starch tests with controls, as well as three food samples. Conduct protein tests with controls, as well as three food samples.  If so, yes go forward, if not go back. Conduct quick tests for fats with eight food samples.  If so, yes go forward, if not go back. Model the gastric digestion of protein. In Activity 5, you will model the salivary digestion of starch.

pageData.content: How to Interpret Biuret Color Change

data.title: Absorption
data.content: The passage of substances through the intestinal mucosa into the blood or lymph

data.title: Activation energy
data.content: The minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction

data.title: Amino acids
data.content: Molecules that contain hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen in the general chemical formula NH2–RCH–COOH, where –R represents a variable group

data.title: Amylase
data.content: An enzyme that catalyzes the breakdown of starch into its component sugars

data.title: Bile salts
data.content: Emulsifiers that are produced by the liver to assist in the emulsification and digestion of lipids,

data.title: Bolus
data.content: Food that has been chewed and mixed with saliva

data.title: Brush border enzyme
data.content: An enzyme associated with microvilli

data.title: Carbohydrate
data.content: An organic compound that contains carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in the general formula (CH2O)n

data.title: Chyme
data.content: A semi-fluid mass of partially digested food and digestive secretions

data.title: Denaturation
data.content: The process of a molecule losing its shape; in enzymes, this also results in the loss of a functional active site

data.title: Dipeptide
data.content: A pair of amino acids

data.title: Disaccharide
data.content: Two chemically-bonded monosaccharides; examples include sucrose (table sugar), maltose, and lactose

data.title: Emulsification
data.content: A process which reduces the attraction between fat molecules and disperses them so large droplets become small droplets that can more readily interact with the enzymes; it is not a chemical reaction

data.title: Enzyme
data.content: A specialized protein that act as a catalyst to speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction

data.title: Enzyme-substrate complex
data.content: A temporary molecule formed when a substrate binds to an enzyme

data.title: Fatty acid
data.content: A carboxylic acid with an aliphatic chain, which is either saturated or unsaturated

data.title: Gastric digestion
data.content: The part of digestion carried out in the stomach by the enzymes in gastric juice

data.title: Glycerol
data.content: A sugar alcohol

data.title: Intestinal digestion
data.content: The part of digestion carried out in the small intestines during which food is broken down into simpler, soluble and diffusible substances

data.title: Lipid
data.content: The most structurally diverse of the biological molecules; this class of compounds includes fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and phospholipids

data.title: Mastication
data.content: Chewing

data.title: Microvilli
data.content: Tiny finger-like extensions of the epithelial cells that greatly increase the surface area for nutrient absorption

data.title: Monomer
data.content: An individual unit of a polymer

data.title: Monosaccharide
data.content: The monomer of carbohydrates and the least complex of the carbohydrate molecules; also known as a simple sugar

data.title: Nucleic acid
data.content: A polymer composed of nucleotide monomers; examples include deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA)

data.title: Nucleotide
data.content: The monomer of nucleic acids; it has three parts: a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Pepsin
data.content: A stomach enzyme that breaks down protein

data.title: Polymer
data.content: A molecule made up of large numbers of repeating units (monomers)

data.title: Polypeptide
data.content: A chain-like polymer composed of amino acid monomers

data.title: Polysaccharide
data.content: The most complex carbohydrates containing several monosaccharides linked in various configurations

data.title: Protein
data.content: A complex organic compound composed of amino acid monomers

data.title: Substrate
data.content: A substance that is acted upon by an enzyme

data.title: Triglyceride
data.content: A molecule containing three fatty acid chains bonded to a glycerol molecule

data.title: Tripeptide
data.content: A chain of three amino acids

data.title: Trypsin
data.content: An enzyme found in the small intestine that breaks down protein
